description: Seed negotiation matrix dataset (example rows plus a few variants).

rows.scenario_label: In-foreclosure, heavy repairs, auction inside 14 days
rows.trigger_phrase: Before we even talk about a number, can I walk you through what the data is saying about this property?
rows.script_body: On the repair side, the scope is coming back heavy between the roof, systems, and interior. On top of that, the payoff letter shows arrears and daily interest still climbing while the auction clock is running. When we plug those into our underwriting engine, it forces us to be conservative so we don't promise you something we can't actually close on.
rows.followup_question: Does that line up with what you've been dealing with on your side?
rows.notes_for_ai: Deliver in a calm, audit-style tone. Do not mention specific dollar amounts here; those will be filled in separately if needed.

rows.scenario_label: Tired landlord, medium repairs, neutral ZIP
rows.trigger_phrase: Let me show you how the numbers come together before I tell you where we can land.
rows.script_body: Your after-repair value in this ZIP, based on recent sales, is around {arv}. From there we back out the actual bids on repairs, the holding costs while it is vacant, and the fees we eat on resale. That leaves a buyer ceiling around {buyer_ceiling} where an investor can still make the project work. Our offer has to sit below that ceiling so we can actually close and take on the risk.
rows.cushioning_statement: With all of that in mind, here is the figure our underwriting engine can realistically support.
rows.followup_question: Before I share the exact number, does that math flow make sense so far?
rows.notes_for_ai: Use {arv} and {buyer_ceiling} placeholders only; do not fabricate numbers. Tone: matter-of-fact, not apologetic.

rows.scenario_label: Equity landlord, slow market, low motivation
rows.motivation_context: Plenty of equity; pain is low but headaches will continue.
rows.trigger_phrase: I might be reading this wrong, but it doesn't sound like you absolutely need to sell this right now.
rows.script_body: Honestly, you could keep the place and ride it out, especially with the equity you have. The trade-off is staying on the hook for the maintenance calls, vacancies, and the slower market in this ZIP. Sometimes the best move is to hold, and sometimes it is to cash out and put that equity into something less hands-on.
rows.followup_question: If you did nothing and just kept it another year, what feels like the upside and what worries you about that path?
rows.notes_for_ai: Be completely non-attached to the outcome. This is a motivation test, not a hard close.

rows.scenario_label: Seller anchored to online value, heavy repairs, slow market
rows.trigger_phrase: Most owners who have looked at the online estimates are worried that anything below that number will feel like a lowball.
rows.script_body: Those online numbers usually assume the house is closer to retail condition. In your case, the bids we have for the roof and interior work are significant, and the sales in this ZIP are taking longer than average. When we layer those repairs and the slower market into the underwriting, it naturally pulls the real investor number below what a website might show on a perfect, updated home.
rows.followup_question: Given all of that, what feels more important to you right now: squeezing every last dollar out, or getting a clean, certain exit?
rows.notes_for_ai: Name the online-estimate concern up front, then pivot to repairs and market speed. Keep tone empathetic but firm.

rows.scenario_label: Borderline confidence, fast ZIP, needs manager review
rows.trigger_phrase: I want to flag that our confidence score on this one is lower because the evidence we have is thin.
rows.script_body: We can move, but only if we keep a safety buffer so we don't overpromise. The repairs are mid-range, the ZIP moves fast, and the FHA 90-day rule is in play, so we need to structure this so compliance and close certainty are intact.
rows.cushioning_statement: Let me outline what we would need to feel good about closing on time.
rows.followup_question: Can you help us shore up any photos or bids so we can tighten this up before we finalize?
rows.notes_for_ai: Keep it factual, emphasize compliance and certainty. Do not provide numbers.

rows.scenario_label: High arrears, payoff shortfall risk, needs payoff transparency
rows.motivation_context: Arrears and auction pressure may force a shortfall vs payoff.
rows.trigger_phrase: The biggest constraint here is the payoff and arrearsâ€”the clock is adding interest daily.
rows.script_body: With the arrears where they are and the repairs this deep, we have to make sure any number we give you is one we can actually close on. The payoff math says we are likely below the total owed, so the offer window we share will be conservative to avoid last-minute surprises.
rows.cushioning_statement: Our goal is to give you a certain, executable number, not a hollow promise.
rows.followup_question: Do you have the latest payoff letter handy so we can make sure we're working off the freshest numbers?
rows.notes_for_ai: Do not state amounts. Keep focus on certainty and payoff math.
